Scoring Phase - Ground Truth Set 20, Ground Truth Question 18, Matched Generated Question 8
Evaluation Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript, a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), and a set of generated MCQs, your task is to:

1. Match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent of the MCQ.

**Transcript**:
Jean-Paul Sartre made thinking and philosophy
glamorous. He was born in Paris in 1905. His father,
a navy captain, died when he was a baby – and he grew up extremely close to his mother until
she remarried, much to his regret, when he was twelve. Sartre spent most of his life in Paris, where
he often went to cafes on the Left Bank. He had a strabismus, a wandering eye, and wore
distinctive, heavy glasses. He was very short (five feet three inches) and frequently described
himself as ugly. By the 60’s Sartre was a household name
in both Europe and the United States, and so was his chosen philosophy, Existentialism. Sartre is famous principally for his book
Being and Nothingness (1943), which enhanced his reputation not so much because people
could understand his ideas  but because they couldn't quite. Existentialism was built around a number of
key insights: One: Things are weirder than we think Sartre is acutely attentive to moments when
the world reveals itself as far stranger and more uncanny than we normally admit; moments
when the logic we ascribe to it day-to-day becomes unavailable, showing things to be
highly contingent and even absurd and frightening. Sartre’s first novel – Nausea, published
in 1938 – is full of evocations of such moments. At one point, the hero, Roquentin,
a 30-year-old writer living in a fictional French seaside town, is on a tram. He puts his hand on the seat, but then pulls
it back rapidly. Instead of being the most basic and obvious piece of design, scarcely
worth a moment’s notice, the seat promptly strikes him as deeply strange; the word ‘seat’ comes loose from its moorings,
the object it refers to shines forth in all its primordial oddity, as if he’s never
seen one before. Roquentin has to force himself to remember that this thing beside him is
something for people to sit on. For a terrifying moment, Roquentin has peered into what Sartre
calls the ‘absurdity of the world.’ Such a moment goes to the heart of Sartre’s
philosophy. To be Sartrean is to be aware of existence as it is when it has been stripped
of any of the prejudices and stabilising assumptions lent to us by our day-to-day routines. We can try out a Sartrean perspective on many
aspects of our own lives. Think of what you know as ‘the evening meal with your partner’. Under such a description, it all seems fairly
logical, but a Sartrean would strip away the surface normality to show the radical strangeness
lurking beneath. Dinner really means that:
when your part of the planet has spun away from the energy of a distant hydrogen and
helium explosion, you slide your knees under strips of a chopped-up
tree and put sections of dead animals and plants
in your mouth and chew, while next to you, another mammal whose genitals
you sometimes touch is doing the same. Two: We are free Such weird moments are certainly disorienting
and rather scary, but Sartre wants to draw our attention to them for one central reason:
because of their liberating dimensions. Life is a lot odder than we think, but it’s
also as a consequence far richer in possibilities. Things don’t have to be quite the way they
are. In the course of fully realising our freedom, we will come up against what Sartre calls the ‘angoisse’ or ‘anguish’ of existence.
Everything is (terrifyingly) possible because nothing has any pre-ordained, God-given sense
or purpose. Humans are just making it up as they go along,
and are free to cast aside the shackles at any moment. Three: We shouldn’t live in ‘Bad faith’ Sartre gave a term to the phenomenon of living
without taking freedom properly on board. He called it BAD FAITH. We are in bad faith whenever we tell ourselves
that things have to be a certain way and shut our eyes to other options. It is bad faith to insist that we have to
do a particular kind of work or live with a specific person or make our home in a given
place. The most famous description of ‘bad faith’
comes in Being and Nothingness, when Sartre notices a waiter who strikes him as overly
devoted to his role, as if he were first and foremost a waiter rather than a free human
being. His movement is quick and forward, a little
too precise, a little too rapid. He comes towards the patrons with a step that is a
little too quick. He bends forward a little too eagerly: his voice, his eyes express an
interest a little too solicitous for the order of the customer…’ The man (he was probably modelled on someone
in Saint-Germain’s Café de Flore) has convinced himself that he is essentially, necessarily
a waiter rather than a free creature who could be a jazz pianist or a fisherman on a North
Sea trawler. Four: We're free to dismantle capitalism. The one factor that most discourages people from experiencing themselves as free is money.
Most of us will shut down a range of possible options (moving abroad, trying out a new career,
leaving a partner) by saying,  ‘that’s if I didn’t have to worry about money.' This passivity in the face of money enraged
Sartre at a political level. He thought of capitalism as a giant machine designed to
create a sense of necessity which doesn’t in fact exist in reality: it makes us tell ourselves we have to work
a certain number of hours, buy a particular product or service, and so on. But in this, there is only the denial of freedom
– and a refusal to take as seriously as we should the possibility of living in other
ways. It was because of these views that Sartre
had a life long interest in Marxism. Marxism seemed in theory to allow people to explore
their freedom, by reducing the role played in their lives by material considerations. Sartre took part in many protests in the streets
of Paris in the 60s. Arrested yet again in 1968, President Charles de Gaulle had him
pardoned, saying, “you don’t arrest Voltaire.” Sartre also visited Fidel Castro and Che Guevara
and admired them both deeply. As a result of these connections and his radical politics,
the FBI kept a large file on Sartre trying to deduce what his suspicious philosophy might
really mean. Sartre is inspiring in his insistence that
things do not have to be the way they are. He is hugely alive to our unfulfilled potential,
as individuals and as a species. He urges us to accept the fluidity of existence and to create new institutions, habits, outlooks
and ideas. The admission that life doesn’t have some
preordained logic and is not inherently meaningful can be a source of immense relief when we
feel oppressed by the weight of tradition and the status quo.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What is "angoisse?"
Options: A. "Anguish," felt because everything is terrifyingly possible, since nothing has God-given purpose., B. "Anger," felt because of the sense of abandonment by God, C. "Apathy," felt because no actions taken by humans matter when their fates after life are out of their control, D. "Awe," felt out of a sense of wonder at how strange the world is and how everything works despite its absurdity
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQ**:
Question: What is the concept of "absurdity of the world" in Sartre's philosophy?
Options: A. The idea that the world is inherently meaningful and logical, B. The notion that human existence is absurd and without purpose, C. The concept that the world is stranger and more uncanny than we normally admit, D. The idea that human freedom is limited by external circumstances
Correct Option: C

   - **Distractor Plausibility (0.0000-1.0000)**: Evaluate the quality of the distractors (incorrect options) in the generated question.
   - **Clarity and Readability (0.0000-1.0000)**: Rate how clear and understandable the question and options are.

glamorous. He was born in Paris in 1905. His father,
a navy captain, died when he was a baby – and he grew up extremely close to his mother until

he often went to cafes on the Left Bank. He had a strabismus, a wandering eye, and wore

himself as ugly. By the 60’s Sartre was a household name

could understand his ideas  but because they couldn't quite. Existentialism was built around a number of
key insights: One: Things are weirder than we think Sartre is acutely attentive to moments when

Scoring Phase - Ground Truth Set 20, Ground Truth Question 20, Matched Generated Question 4

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript, a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), and a set of generated MCQs, your task is to:

**Transcript**:
Jean-Paul Sartre made thinking and philosophy
glamorous. He was born in Paris in 1905. His father,
a navy captain, died when he was a baby – and he grew up extremely close to his mother until
she remarried, much to his regret, when he was twelve. Sartre spent most of his life in Paris, where
he often went to cafes on the Left Bank. He had a strabismus, a wandering eye, and wore
distinctive, heavy glasses. He was very short (five feet three inches) and frequently described

in both Europe and the United States, and so was his chosen philosophy, Existentialism. Sartre is famous principally for his book
Being and Nothingness (1943), which enhanced his reputation not so much because people
could understand his ideas  but because they couldn't quite. Existentialism was built around a number of
key insights: One: Things are weirder than we think Sartre is acutely attentive to moments when
the world reveals itself as far stranger and more uncanny than we normally admit; moments

their freedom, by reducing the role played in their lives by material considerations. Sartre took part in many protests in the streets
of Paris in the 60s. Arrested yet again in 1968, President Charles de Gaulle had him
pardoned, saying, “you don’t arrest Voltaire.” Sartre also visited Fidel Castro and Che Guevara
and admired them both deeply. As a result of these connections and his radical politics,
the FBI kept a large file on Sartre trying to deduce what his suspicious philosophy might
really mean. Sartre is inspiring in his insistence that
things do not have to be the way they are. He is hugely alive to our unfulfilled potential,
as individuals and as a species. He urges us to accept the fluidity of existence and to create new institutions, habits, outlooks
and ideas. The admission that life doesn’t have some
preordained logic and is not inherently meaningful can be a source of immense relief when we
feel oppressed by the weight of tradition and the status quo.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What is the name of Sartre's first novel?
Options: A. The Plague, B. Nausea, C. Love in the Time of Cholera, D. Evocation
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQ**:
Question: What was the title of Sartre's first novel, published in 1938?
Options: A. Being and Nothingness, B. Nausea, C. The Stranger, D. The Absurd
Correct Option: B

Scoring Phase - Ground Truth Set 20, Ground Truth Question 21, Matched Generated Question 8
Evaluation Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript, a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), and a set of generated MCQs, your task is to:

1. Match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent of the MCQ.

**Transcript**:
Jean-Paul Sartre made thinking and philosophy
glamorous. He was born in Paris in 1905. His father,
a navy captain, died when he was a baby – and he grew up extremely close to his mother until
she remarried, much to his regret, when he was twelve. Sartre spent most of his life in Paris, where
he often went to cafes on the Left Bank. He had a strabismus, a wandering eye, and wore
distinctive, heavy glasses. He was very short (five feet three inches) and frequently described
himself as ugly. By the 60’s Sartre was a household name
in both Europe and the United States, and so was his chosen philosophy, Existentialism. Sartre is famous principally for his book
Being and Nothingness (1943), which enhanced his reputation not so much because people
could understand his ideas  but because they couldn't quite. Existentialism was built around a number of
key insights: One: Things are weirder than we think Sartre is acutely attentive to moments when
the world reveals itself as far stranger and more uncanny than we normally admit; moments
when the logic we ascribe to it day-to-day becomes unavailable, showing things to be
highly contingent and even absurd and frightening. Sartre’s first novel – Nausea, published
in 1938 – is full of evocations of such moments. At one point, the hero, Roquentin,
a 30-year-old writer living in a fictional French seaside town, is on a tram. He puts his hand on the seat, but then pulls
it back rapidly. Instead of being the most basic and obvious piece of design, scarcely
worth a moment’s notice, the seat promptly strikes him as deeply strange; the word ‘seat’ comes loose from its moorings,
the object it refers to shines forth in all its primordial oddity, as if he’s never
seen one before. Roquentin has to force himself to remember that this thing beside him is
something for people to sit on. For a terrifying moment, Roquentin has peered into what Sartre
calls the ‘absurdity of the world.’ Such a moment goes to the heart of Sartre’s
philosophy. To be Sartrean is to be aware of existence as it is when it has been stripped
of any of the prejudices and stabilising assumptions lent to us by our day-to-day routines. We can try out a Sartrean perspective on many
aspects of our own lives. Think of what you know as ‘the evening meal with your partner’. Under such a description, it all seems fairly
logical, but a Sartrean would strip away the surface normality to show the radical strangeness
lurking beneath. Dinner really means that:
when your part of the planet has spun away from the energy of a distant hydrogen and
helium explosion, you slide your knees under strips of a chopped-up
tree and put sections of dead animals and plants
in your mouth and chew, while next to you, another mammal whose genitals
you sometimes touch is doing the same. Two: We are free Such weird moments are certainly disorienting
and rather scary, but Sartre wants to draw our attention to them for one central reason:
because of their liberating dimensions. Life is a lot odder than we think, but it’s
also as a consequence far richer in possibilities. Things don’t have to be quite the way they
are. In the course of fully realising our freedom, we will come up against what Sartre calls the ‘angoisse’ or ‘anguish’ of existence.
Everything is (terrifyingly) possible because nothing has any pre-ordained, God-given sense
or purpose. Humans are just making it up as they go along,
and are free to cast aside the shackles at any moment. Three: We shouldn’t live in ‘Bad faith’ Sartre gave a term to the phenomenon of living
without taking freedom properly on board. He called it BAD FAITH. We are in bad faith whenever we tell ourselves
that things have to be a certain way and shut our eyes to other options. It is bad faith to insist that we have to
do a particular kind of work or live with a specific person or make our home in a given
place. The most famous description of ‘bad faith’
comes in Being and Nothingness, when Sartre notices a waiter who strikes him as overly
devoted to his role, as if he were first and foremost a waiter rather than a free human
being. His movement is quick and forward, a little
too precise, a little too rapid. He comes towards the patrons with a step that is a
little too quick. He bends forward a little too eagerly: his voice, his eyes express an
interest a little too solicitous for the order of the customer…’ The man (he was probably modelled on someone
in Saint-Germain’s Café de Flore) has convinced himself that he is essentially, necessarily
a waiter rather than a free creature who could be a jazz pianist or a fisherman on a North
Sea trawler. Four: We're free to dismantle capitalism. The one factor that most discourages people from experiencing themselves as free is money.
Most of us will shut down a range of possible options (moving abroad, trying out a new career,
leaving a partner) by saying,  ‘that’s if I didn’t have to worry about money.' This passivity in the face of money enraged
Sartre at a political level. He thought of capitalism as a giant machine designed to
create a sense of necessity which doesn’t in fact exist in reality: it makes us tell ourselves we have to work
a certain number of hours, buy a particular product or service, and so on. But in this, there is only the denial of freedom
– and a refusal to take as seriously as we should the possibility of living in other
ways. It was because of these views that Sartre
had a life long interest in Marxism. Marxism seemed in theory to allow people to explore
their freedom, by reducing the role played in their lives by material considerations. Sartre took part in many protests in the streets
of Paris in the 60s. Arrested yet again in 1968, President Charles de Gaulle had him
pardoned, saying, “you don’t arrest Voltaire.” Sartre also visited Fidel Castro and Che Guevara
and admired them both deeply. As a result of these connections and his radical politics,
the FBI kept a large file on Sartre trying to deduce what his suspicious philosophy might
really mean. Sartre is inspiring in his insistence that
things do not have to be the way they are. He is hugely alive to our unfulfilled potential,
as individuals and as a species. He urges us to accept the fluidity of existence and to create new institutions, habits, outlooks
and ideas. The admission that life doesn’t have some
preordained logic and is not inherently meaningful can be a source of immense relief when we
feel oppressed by the weight of tradition and the status quo.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Nausea protagonist Roquentin is overwhelmed by the profound absurdity of which ordinary object?
Options: A. Pole, B. Wire, C. Seat, D. Window
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQ**:
Question: What is the concept of "absurdity of the world" in Sartre's philosophy?
Options: A. The idea that the world is inherently meaningful and logical, B. The notion that human existence is absurd and without purpose, C. The concept that the world is stranger and more uncanny than we normally admit, D. The idea that human freedom is limited by external circumstances
Correct Option: C

2. Evaluate each matched MCQ pair based on the following criteria:
   - **Relevance (0.0000 - 1.0000)**: Assess how closely the generated question aligns with the content and intent of the ground truth question.
   - **Correct Answer Matching (0.0000 - 1.0000)**: Check if the correct answer option in the generated question matches the ground truth answer.
   - **Distractor Plausibility (0.0000-1.0000)**: Evaluate the quality of the distractors (incorrect options) in the generated question.
   - **Clarity and Readability (0.0000-1.0000)**: Rate how clear and understandable the question and options are.

**Response Format**:
1. **MCQ Pair**: Display both the Ground Truth and Generated MCQ.
2. **Scores**:
   - Relevance Score: X.XXXX
   - Correct Answer Matching Score: X.XXXX
   - Distractor Plausibility Score: X.XXXX
   - Clarity and Readability Score: X.XXXX
   - Total Score: X.XXXX

Question: Nausea protagonist Roquentin is overwhelmed by the profound absurdity of which ordinary object?
Options: A. Pole, B. Wire, C. Seat, D. Window
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQ**:
Question: What is the concept of "absurdity of the world" in Sartre's philosophy?
Options: A. The idea that the world is inherently meaningful and logical, B. The notion that human existence is absurd and without purpose, C. The concept that the world is stranger and more uncanny than we normally admit, D. The idea that human freedom is limited by external circumstances
Correct Option: C

**Scores**:

- Correct Answer Matching Score: 0.0000 (The correct answer in the generated question does not match the ground truth answer.)
- Distractor Plausibility Score: 0.8000 (The distractors in the generated question are plausible and well-written, but they don't match the options in the ground truth question.)
- Clarity and Readability Score: 0.9000 (The generated question and options are clear and easy to understand.)

Question: How do we see "the absurdity of the world?"

**Transcript**:
Jean-Paul Sartre made thinking and philosophy
glamorous. He was born in Paris in 1905. His father,
a navy captain, died when he was a baby – and he grew up extremely close to his mother until
she remarried, much to his regret, when he was twelve. Sartre spent most of his life in Paris, where
he often went to cafes on the Left Bank. He had a strabismus, a wandering eye, and wore
distinctive, heavy glasses. He was very short (five feet three inches) and frequently described
himself as ugly. By the 60’s Sartre was a household name
in both Europe and the United States, and so was his chosen philosophy, Existentialism. Sartre is famous principally for his book
Being and Nothingness (1943), which enhanced his reputation not so much because people
could understand his ideas  but because they couldn't quite. Existentialism was built around a number of
key insights: One: Things are weirder than we think Sartre is acutely attentive to moments when
the world reveals itself as far stranger and more uncanny than we normally admit; moments
when the logic we ascribe to it day-to-day becomes unavailable, showing things to be
highly contingent and even absurd and frightening. Sartre’s first novel – Nausea, published
in 1938 – is full of evocations of such moments. At one point, the hero, Roquentin,
a 30-year-old writer living in a fictional French seaside town, is on a tram. He puts his hand on the seat, but then pulls
it back rapidly. Instead of being the most basic and obvious piece of design, scarcely
worth a moment’s notice, the seat promptly strikes him as deeply strange; the word ‘seat’ comes loose from its moorings,
the object it refers to shines forth in all its primordial oddity, as if he’s never
seen one before. Roquentin has to force himself to remember that this thing beside him is

calls the ‘absurdity of the world.’ Such a moment goes to the heart of Sartre’s
philosophy. To be Sartrean is to be aware of existence as it is when it has been stripped
of any of the prejudices and stabilising assumptions lent to us by our day-to-day routines. We can try out a Sartrean perspective on many

logical, but a Sartrean would strip away the surface normality to show the radical strangeness

when your part of the planet has spun away from the energy of a distant hydrogen and

in your mouth and chew, while next to you, another mammal whose genitals

and rather scary, but Sartre wants to draw our attention to them for one central reason:
because of their liberating dimensions. Life is a lot odder than we think, but it’s

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What is "bad faith?"
Options: A. Living without taking freedom properly on board; telling ourselves that things have to be a certain way, shutting our eyes to other options., B. Failing to worship a deity with the full piousness and devotion they deserve, C. Breaking promises to others frequently, thus creating a chain reaction of broken trust in society, D. Refusing to help others because of our belief that they deserve their bad conditions
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQ**:
Question: What is the term Sartre used to describe living without taking freedom properly on board?
Options: A. Existentialism, B. Bad Faith, C. Nihilism, D. Absurdism
Correct Option: B

**MCQ Pair**:

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What is "bad faith?"
Options: A. Living without taking freedom properly on board; telling ourselves that things have to be a certain way, shutting our eyes to other options., B. Failing to worship a deity with the full piousness and devotion they deserve, C. Breaking promises to others frequently, thus creating a chain reaction of broken trust in society, D. Refusing to help others because of our belief that they deserve their bad conditions
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQ**:
Question: What is the term Sartre used to describe living without taking freedom properly on board?
Options: A. Existentialism, B. Bad Faith, C. Nihilism, D. Absurdism
Correct Option: B

**Scores**:
- Relevance Score: 0.9000 (The generated question is highly relevant to the ground truth question, as it directly asks about the term Sartre used to describe the concept of living without taking freedom properly on board, which is the definition of "bad faith.")
- Correct Answer Matching Score: 1.0000 (The correct answer option in the generated question, "Bad Faith," matches the ground truth answer, which is the definition of "bad faith.")
- Distractor Plausibility Score: 0.8000 (The distractors in the generated question, "Existentialism," "Nihilism," and "Absurdism," are plausible but not as strong as they could be, as they are all related to philosophical concepts and might not be immediately recognizable as incorrect options for non-experts.)
- Clarity and Readability Score: 0.9000 (The question and options are clear and understandable, but the generated question could be slightly improved by making it more concise and direct.)
- Total Score: 0.9000

Scoring Phase - Ground Truth Set 21, Ground Truth Question 1, Matched Generated Question 8
Evaluation Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript, a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), and a set of generated MCQs, your task is to:

1. Match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent of the MCQ.

**Transcript**:
combined trends of increased inequality and decreasing mobility President Obama has made a big push to address the income gap this year and he'll likely bring this up during Tuesday's State of the Union speech so what's it like out there it turns out US income inequality is at its highest point since 1928 the richest 10% of Americans taken 50% of the country's income here is the change from just 30 years ago a new poll by the Pew Research Center in USA Today found Americans are keenly aware of this gap 65 percent believe it has grown in the past decade but there's a clear partisan divide about what to do 90 percent yes 90 percent of Democrats think the government should take on reducing the income gap but only 45 percent of Republicans are for government to help one thing that hasn't changed much over the years is the income gap between races if we look at median incomes all this wealth disparity can lead to some strong opinions in the u.s. when asked if the rich are more likely to be greedy 55 percent of Americans said yes and are the rich more likely to be honest only 12 percent thought so as for the poor 38 percent of Americans said a lack of work ethic was to blame for financial straits so how does the u.s. fare in the global context after taxes America ranks second for income inequality in the developed world one survey of top global leaders pegged income disparity as the second gravest trend facing the world it was issue number one for specific regions back in the u.s. President Obama faces a constituency United over the problem but divided on solutions as for the economic system itself only 36 percent of Americans feel it's fair to everyone David Botti BBC News Washington

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: True or false: most Americans are aware that income inequality has grown in the past decade.
Options: A. True, B. False
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQ**:
Question: What is the percentage of Americans who believe that the rich are more likely to be greedy, according to the transcript?
Options: A. 30%, B. 40%, C. 55%, D. 60%
Correct Option: C

   - **Relevance (0.0000 - 1.0000)**: Assess how closely the generated question aligns with the content and intent of the ground truth question.
   - **Correct Answer Matching (0.0000 - 1.0000)**: Check if the correct answer option in the generated question matches the ground truth answer.
   - **Distractor Plausibility (0.0000-1.0000)**: Evaluate the quality of the distractors (incorrect options) in the generated question.
   - **Clarity and Readability (0.0000-1.0000)**: Rate how clear and understandable the question and options are.

**Response Format**:
1. **MCQ Pair**: Display both the Ground Truth and Generated MCQ.
2. **Scores**:
   - Relevance Score: X.XXXX
   - Correct Answer Matching Score: X.XXXX
   - Distractor Plausibility Score: X.XXXX
   - Clarity and Readability Score: X.XXXX
   - Total Score: X.XXXX

**Ground Truth MCQ**:

Options: A. True, B. False
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQ** (Most Similar):

Options: A. 40%, B. 50%, C. 65%, D. 75%
Correct Option: C

**Scores**:
- Relevance Score: 0.9000 (The generated question is closely related to the ground truth question, but it asks for a specific percentage instead of a true/false answer.)
- Correct Answer Matching Score: 1.0000 (The correct answer option in the generated question matches the ground truth answer, as 65% of Americans believe that income inequality has grown in the past decade.)
- Distractor Plausibility Score: 0.8000 (The distractors in the generated question are plausible, but they could be more challenging and realistic.)
- Clarity and Readability Score: 1.0000 (The question and options are clear and easy to understand.)

combined trends of increased inequality and decreasing mobility President Obama has made a big push to address the income gap this year and he'll likely bring this up during Tuesday's State of the Union speech so what's it like out there it turns out US income inequality is at its highest point since 1928 the richest 10% of Americans taken 50% of the country's income here is the change from just 30 years ago a new poll by the Pew Research Center in USA Today found Americans are keenly aware of this gap 65 percent believe it has grown in the past decade but there's a clear partisan divide about what to do 90 percent yes 90 percent of Democrats think the government should take on reducing the income gap but only 45 percent of Republicans are for government to help one thing that hasn't changed much over the years is the income gap between races if we look at median incomes all this wealth disparity can lead to some strong opinions in the u.s. when asked if the rich are more likely to be greedy 55 percent of Americans said yes and are the rich more likely to be honest only 12 percent thought so as for the poor 38 percent of Americans said a lack of work ethic was to blame for financial straits so how does the u.s. fare in the global context after taxes America ranks second for income inequality in the developed world one survey of top global leaders pegged income disparity as the second gravest trend facing the world it was issue number one for specific regions back in the u.s. Correct Option: B

Correct Option: D

Options: A. The income gap between races has decreased significantly over the years., B. The income gap between races has increased significantly over the years., C. The income gap between races has remained relatively stable over the years., D. The income gap between races is no longer a significant issue.
Correct Option: C

Question: The racial income gap has...
Options: A. Disappeared, with equal earning regardless of race, B. Gotten significantly worse, with whites earning significantly less, C. Gotten significantly worse, with blacks earning less than whites, D. Stayed about the same
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQ**:
Question: What can be inferred from the statement: "One thing that hasn't changed much over the years is the income gap between races"?
Options: A. The income gap between races has decreased significantly over the years., B. The income gap between races has increased significantly over the years., C. The income gap between races has remained relatively stable over the years., D. The income gap between races is no longer a significant issue.
Correct Option: C

Scoring Phase - Ground Truth Set 21, Ground Truth Question 8, Matched Generated Question 8
Evaluation Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript, a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), and a set of generated MCQs, your task is to:

1. Match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent of the MCQ.

**Transcript**:
combined trends of increased inequality and decreasing mobility President Obama has made a big push to address the income gap this year and he'll likely bring this up during Tuesday's State of the Union speech so what's it like out there it turns out US income inequality is at its highest point since 1928 the richest 10% of Americans taken 50% of the country's income here is the change from just 30 years ago a new poll by the Pew Research Center in USA Today found Americans are keenly aware of this gap 65 percent believe it has grown in the past decade but there's a clear partisan divide about what to do 90 percent yes 90 percent of Democrats think the government should take on reducing the income gap but only 45 percent of Republicans are for government to help one thing that hasn't changed much over the years is the income gap between races if we look at median incomes all this wealth disparity can lead to some strong opinions in the u.s. when asked if the rich are more likely to be greedy 55 percent of Americans said yes and are the rich more likely to be honest only 12 percent thought so as for the poor 38 percent of Americans said a lack of work ethic was to blame for financial straits so how does the u.s. fare in the global context after taxes America ranks second for income inequality in the developed world one survey of top global leaders pegged income disparity as the second gravest trend facing the world it was issue number one for specific regions back in the u.s. President Obama faces a constituency United over the problem but divided on solutions as for the economic system itself only 36 percent of Americans feel it's fair to everyone David Botti BBC News Washington

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: True or false: most Americans are aware that income inequality has grown in the past decade.
Options: A. True, B. False
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQ**:
Question: What is the percentage of Americans who believe that the rich are more likely to be greedy, according to the transcript?
Options: A. 30%, B. 40%, C. 55%, D. 60%
Correct Option: C

2. Evaluate each matched MCQ pair based on the following criteria:
   - **Relevance (0.0000 - 1.0000)**: Assess how closely the generated question aligns with the content and intent of the ground truth question.
   - **Correct Answer Matching (0.0000 - 1.0000)**: Check if the correct answer option in the generated question matches the ground truth answer.
   - **Distractor Plausibility (0.0000-1.0000)**: Evaluate the quality of the distractors (incorrect options) in the generated question.
   - **Clarity and Readability (0.0000-1.0000)**: Rate how clear and understandable the question and options are.

**Response Format**:
1. **MCQ Pair**: Display both the Ground Truth and Generated MCQ.
2. **Scores**:
   - Relevance Score: X.XXXX
   - Correct Answer Matching Score: X.XXXX
   - Distractor Plausibility Score: X.XXXX
   - Clarity and Readability Score: X.XXXX
   - Total Score: X.XXXX

Evaluation Response:

**Ground Truth MCQ**:

Options: A. True, B. False
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQ** (Most Similar):

Options: A. 40%, B. 50%, C. 65%, D. 75%
Correct Option: C

**Scores**:

Scoring Phase - Ground Truth Set 21, Ground Truth Question 10, Matched Generated Question 4
Evaluation Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript, a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), and a set of generated MCQs, your task is to:

1. Match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent of the MCQ.

**Transcript**:
combined trends of increased inequality and decreasing mobility President Obama has made a big push to address the income gap this year and he'll likely bring this up during Tuesday's State of the Union speech so what's it like out there it turns out US income inequality is at its highest point since 1928 the richest 10% of Americans taken 50% of the country's income here is the change from just 30 years ago a new poll by the Pew Research Center in USA Today found Americans are keenly aware of this gap 65 percent believe it has grown in the past decade but there's a clear partisan divide about what to do 90 percent yes 90 percent of Democrats think the government should take on reducing the income gap but only 45 percent of Republicans are for government to help one thing that hasn't changed much over the years is the income gap between races if we look at median incomes all this wealth disparity can lead to some strong opinions in the u.s. when asked if the rich are more likely to be greedy 55 percent of Americans said yes and are the rich more likely to be honest only 12 percent thought so as for the poor 38 percent of Americans said a lack of work ethic was to blame for financial straits so how does the u.s. fare in the global context after taxes America ranks second for income inequality in the developed world one survey of top global leaders pegged income disparity as the second gravest trend facing the world it was issue number one for specific regions back in the u.s. President Obama faces a constituency United over the problem but divided on solutions as for the economic system itself only 36 percent of Americans feel it's fair to everyone David Botti BBC News Washington

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The racial income gap has...
Options: A. Disappeared, with equal earning regardless of race, B. Gotten significantly worse, with whites earning significantly less, C. Gotten significantly worse, with blacks earning less than whites, D. Stayed about the same
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQ**:
Question: What can be inferred from the statement: "One thing that hasn't changed much over the years is the income gap between races"?
Options: A. The income gap between races has decreased significantly over the years., B. The income gap between races has increased significantly over the years., C. The income gap between races has remained relatively stable over the years., D. The income gap between races is no longer a significant issue.
Correct Option: C

2. Evaluate each matched MCQ pair based on the following criteria:
   - **Relevance (0.0000 - 1.0000)**: Assess how closely the generated question aligns with the content and intent of the ground truth question.
   - **Correct Answer Matching (0.0000 - 1.0000)**: Check if the correct answer option in the generated question matches the ground truth answer.

2. **Scores**:

   - Correct Answer Matching Score: X.XXXX
   - Distractor Plausibility Score: X.XXXX
   - Clarity and Readability Score: X.XXXX
   - Total Score: X.XXXX

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The racial income gap has...
Options: A. Disappeared, with equal earning regardless of race, B. Gotten significantly worse, with whites earning significantly less, C. Gotten significantly worse, with blacks earning less than whites, D. Stayed about the same
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQ**:

Options: A. The income gap between races has decreased significantly over the years., B. The income gap between races has increased significantly over the years., C. The income gap between races has remained relatively stable over the years., D. The income gap between races is no longer a significant issue.
Correct Option: C

**Scores**

combined trends of increased inequality and decreasing mobility President Obama has made a big push to address the income gap this year and he'll likely bring this up during Tuesday's State of the Union speech so what's it like out there it turns out US income inequality is at its highest point since 1928 the richest 10% of Americans taken 50% of the country's income here is the change from just 30 years ago a new poll by the Pew Research Center in USA Today found Americans are keenly aware of this gap 65 percent believe it has grown in the past decade but there's a clear partisan divide about what to do 90 percent yes 90 percent of Democrats think the government should take on reducing the income gap but only 45 percent of Republicans are for government to help one thing that hasn't changed much over the years is the income gap between races if we look at median incomes all this wealth disparity can lead to some strong opinions in the u.s. when asked if the rich are more likely to be greedy 55 percent of Americans said yes and are the rich more likely to be honest only 12 percent thought so as for the poor 38 percent of Americans said a lack of work ethic was to blame for financial straits so how does the u.s. fare in the global context after taxes America ranks second for income inequality in the developed world one survey of top global leaders pegged income disparity as the second gravest trend facing the world it was issue number one for specific regions back in the u.s. President Obama faces a constituency United over the problem but divided on solutions as for the economic system itself only 36 percent of Americans feel it's fair to everyone David Botti BBC News Washington

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The richest 10% of Americans take in what percentage of the country's income?
Options: A. 25%, B. 40%, C. 50%, D. 75%
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQ**:
Question: According to the transcript, what percentage of the country's income is taken by the richest 10% of Americans?
Options: A. 30%, B. 40%, C. 50%, D. 60%
Correct Option: C

   - **Relevance (0.0000 - 1.0000)**: Assess how closely the generated question aligns with the content and intent of the ground truth question.

Scoring Phase - Ground Truth Set 22, Ground Truth Question 1, Matched Generated Question 2
Evaluation Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript, a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), and a set of generated MCQs, your task is to:

1. Match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent of the MCQ.

**Transcript**:
if a sinister looking man carrying an axe knocked on your door and asked you where your best friend was would it be morally acceptable to tell a lie Immanuel Kant surprisingly thought it wouldn't the example of the would-be murderer is his tell the truth is what Kant called a categorical imperative an absolute duty one without exceptions it applies to everyone whatever the consequences in fact Kant argued that if you told a lie which by chance led to the ax man finding your friend that would be on your conscience so if you tell the axe man that your friend is not in the house when he is and your friend then sneaks out the back door and bumps in the ax man anything that then happens is to some extent your responsibility but if you told the truth then the consequences for your friend no matter how grisly should not be on your conscience this brings out how different his moral stance was from utilitarianism the philosophy that you should do whatever brings about the greatest happiness a utilitarian would think about the consequences of telling the truth or of lying in contrast for Kant some actions were just wrong even if good consequences might flow from them this is known as a deontological approach to ethics you

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What is the "categorical imperative?"
Options: A. A code of ethics that is easily categorized, B. Something you must do only in certain situations, C. An absolute duty, one without exceptions, D. An action to take when you have no other options
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQ**:
Question: What term did Immanuel Kant use to describe a moral principle that is absolute and applies to everyone without exceptions?
Options: A. Moral principle, B. Categorical imperative, C. Universal law, D. Ethical maxim
Correct Option: B

2. Evaluate each matched MCQ pair based on the following criteria:
   - **Relevance (0.0000 - 1.0000)**: Assess how closely the generated question aligns with the content and intent of the ground truth question.
   - **Correct Answer Matching (0.0000 - 1.0000)**: Check if the correct answer option in the generated question matches the ground truth answer.
   - **Distractor Plausibility (0.0000-1.0000)**: Evaluate the quality of the distractors (incorrect options) in the generated question.
   - **Clarity and Readability (0.0000-1.0000)**: Rate how clear and understandable the question and options are.

**Response Format**:
1. **MCQ Pair**: Display both the Ground Truth and Generated MCQ.
2. **Scores**:
   - Relevance Score: X.XXXX
   - Correct Answer Matching Score: X.XXXX
   - Distractor Plausibility Score: X.XXXX
   - Clarity and Readability Score: X.XXXX
   - Total Score: X.XXXX

Evaluation Response:
**MCQ Pair**

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What is the "categorical imperative?"
Options: A. A code of ethics that is easily categorized, B. Something you must do only in certain situations, C. An absolute duty, one without exceptions, D. An action to take when you have no other options
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQ**:
Question: What term did Immanuel Kant use to describe a moral principle that is absolute and applies to everyone without exceptions?
Options: A. Moral principle, B. Categorical imperative, C. Universal law, D. Ethical maxim
Correct Option: B

**Scores**

- Relevance Score: 0.9000 (The generated question closely aligns with the content and intent of the ground truth question, but is phrased differently.)
- Correct Answer Matching Score: 1.0000 (The correct answer option in the generated question matches the ground truth answer, although the wording of the options is different.)
- Distractor Plausibility Score: 0.8000 (The distractors in the generated question are plausible but could be improved. Options A and D are somewhat generic, while option C, "Universal law", could be a more effective distractor if it were more directly related to Kant's philosophy.)

Scoring Phase - Ground Truth Set 22, Ground Truth Question 2, Matched Generated Question 7
Evaluation Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript, a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), and a set of generated MCQs, your task is to:

1. Match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent of the MCQ.

**Transcript**:
if a sinister looking man carrying an axe knocked on your door and asked you where your best friend was would it be morally acceptable to tell a lie Immanuel Kant surprisingly thought it wouldn't the example of the would-be murderer is his tell the truth is what Kant called a categorical imperative an absolute duty one without exceptions it applies to everyone whatever the consequences in fact Kant argued that if you told a lie which by chance led to the ax man finding your friend that would be on your conscience so if you tell the axe man that your friend is not in the house when he is and your friend then sneaks out the back door and bumps in the ax man anything that then happens is to some extent your responsibility but if you told the truth then the consequences for your friend no matter how grisly should not be on your conscience this brings out how different his moral stance was from utilitarianism the philosophy that you should do whatever brings about the greatest happiness a utilitarian would think about the consequences of telling the truth or of lying in contrast for Kant some actions were just wrong even if good consequences might flow from them this is known as a deontological approach to ethics you

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What is utilitarianism?
Options: A. A philosophy that you should do whatever brings about the greatest happiness, B. A philosophy that dictates everything must be functional, C. A style of art that emphasizes minimalist design, D. A religion that encourages worship of the goddess Utilitaria
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQ**:
Question: What would a utilitarian primarily consider when deciding whether to tell the truth or lie to the axe man?
Options: A. The moral principle of honesty, B. The consequences of telling the truth or lying, C. The axe man's intentions, D. The friend's character
Correct Option: B

2. Evaluate each matched MCQ pair based on the following criteria:
   - **Relevance (0.0000 - 1.0000)**: Assess how closely the generated question aligns with the content and intent of the ground truth question.
   - **Correct Answer Matching (0.0000 - 1.0000)**: Check if the correct answer option in the generated question matches the ground truth answer.
   - **Distractor Plausibility (0.0000-1.0000)**: Evaluate the quality of the distractors (incorrect options) in the generated question.
   - **Clarity and Readability (0.0000-1.0000)**: Rate how clear and understandable the question and options are.

**Response Format**:
1. **MCQ Pair**: Display both the Ground Truth and Generated MCQ.
2. **Scores**:
   - Relevance Score: X.XXXX
   - Correct Answer Matching Score: X.XXXX
   - Distractor Plausibility Score: X.XXXX
   - Clarity and Readability Score: X.XXXX
   - Total Score: X.XXXX

Evaluation Response:
**MCQ Pair**:

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What is utilitarianism?
Options: A. A philosophy that you should do whatever brings about the greatest happiness, B. A philosophy that dictates everything must be functional, C. A style of art that emphasizes minimalist design, D. A religion that encourages worship of the goddess Utilitaria
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQ**:
Question: What would a utilitarian primarily consider when deciding whether to tell the truth or lie to the axe man?
Options: A. The moral principle of honesty, B. The consequences of telling the truth or lying, C. The axe man's intentions, D. The friend's character
Correct Option: B

**Scores**:
- Relevance Score: 0.8000 (The generated question is related to utilitarianism, but it doesn't directly ask for a definition. Instead, it asks about the application of utilitarian principles in a specific scenario.)
- Correct Answer Matching Score: 0.0000 (The correct answer options do not match. The ground truth MCQ defines utilitarianism, while the generated MCQ describes how a utilitarian would approach a situation.)
- Distractor Plausibility Score: 0.8000 (The distractors in the generated MCQ are plausible, but they could be more challenging. Options A and C are somewhat related to the scenario, while option D seems less relevant.)
- Clarity and Readability Score: 0.9000 (Both the question and options in the generated MCQ are clear and easy to understand.)
- Total Score: 0.6250

Scoring Phase - Ground Truth Set 22, Ground Truth Question 3, Matched Generated Question 7
Evaluation Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript, a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), and a set of generated MCQs, your task is to:

1. Match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent of the MCQ.

**Transcript**:
if a sinister looking man carrying an axe knocked on your door and asked you where your best friend was would it be morally acceptable to tell a lie Immanuel Kant surprisingly thought it wouldn't the example of the would-be murderer is his tell the truth is what Kant called a categorical imperative an absolute duty one without exceptions it applies to everyone whatever the consequences in fact Kant argued that if you told a lie which by chance led to the ax man finding your friend that would be on your conscience so if you tell the axe man that your friend is not in the house when he is and your friend then sneaks out the back door and bumps in the ax man anything that then happens is to some extent your responsibility but if you told the truth then the consequences for your friend no matter how grisly should not be on your conscience this brings out how different his moral stance was from utilitarianism the philosophy that you should do whatever brings about the greatest happiness a utilitarian would think about the consequences of telling the truth or of lying in contrast for Kant some actions were just wrong even if good consequences might flow from them this is known as a deontological approach to ethics you

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: A utilitarian would evaluate __________ of a decision while a deontologist, like Kant, would evaluate the morality of the decision by itself.
Options: A. Costliness, B. Public perceptions, C. Time investment, D. Consequences
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQ**:
Question: What would a utilitarian primarily consider when deciding whether to tell the truth or lie to the axe man?
Options: A. The moral principle of honesty, B. The consequences of telling the truth or lying, C. The axe man's intentions, D. The friend's character
Correct Option: B

2. Evaluate each matched MCQ pair based on the following criteria:
   - **Relevance (0.0000 - 1.0000)**: Assess how closely the generated question aligns with the content and intent of the ground truth question.
   - **Correct Answer Matching (0.0000 - 1.0000)**: Check if the correct answer option in the generated question matches the ground truth answer.
   - **Distractor Plausibility (0.0000-1.0000)**: Evaluate the quality of the distractors (incorrect options) in the generated question.
   - **Clarity and Readability (0.0000-1.0000)**: Rate how clear and understandable the question and options are.

**Response Format**:
1. **MCQ Pair**: Display both the Ground Truth and Generated MCQ.
2. **Scores**:
   - Relevance Score: X.XXXX
   - Correct Answer Matching Score: X.XXXX
   - Distractor Plausibility Score: X.XXXX
   - Clarity and Readability Score: X.XXXX
   - Total Score: X.XXXX

Evaluation Response:
**MCQ Pair**

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: A utilitarian would evaluate __________ of a decision while a deontologist, like Kant, would evaluate the morality of the decision by itself.
Options: A. Costliness, B. Public perceptions, C. Time investment, D. Consequences
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQ**:
Question: What would a utilitarian primarily consider when deciding whether to tell the truth or lie to the axe man?
Options: A. The moral principle of honesty, B. The consequences of telling the truth or lying, C. The axe man's intentions, D. The friend's character
Correct Option: B

**Scores**

- Relevance Score: 0.9000 (The generated question is highly relevant to the ground truth question, as both questions focus on the utilitarian perspective and its emphasis on consequences. However, the generated question is more specific to the scenario, whereas the ground truth question is more general.)
- Correct Answer Matching Score: 1.0000 (The correct answer option in the generated question (B. The consequences of telling the truth or lying) matches the ground truth answer (D. Consequences).)
- Distractor Plausibility Score: 0.8000 (The distractors in the generated question are plausible, but not as strong as those in the ground truth question. Options A and D in the generated question are less convincing as distractors compared to options A, B, and C in the ground truth question.)
- Clarity and Readability Score: 0.9500 (The generated question and options are clear and easy to understand, with only minor room for improvement in terms of concision.)
- Total Score: 0.9125

Scoring Phase - Ground Truth Set 22, Ground Truth Question 4, Matched Generated Question 1
Evaluation Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript, a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), and a set of generated MCQs, your task is to:

**Transcript**:
if a sinister looking man carrying an axe knocked on your door and asked you where your best friend was would it be morally acceptable to tell a lie Immanuel Kant surprisingly thought it wouldn't the example of the would-be murderer is his tell the truth is what Kant called a categorical imperative an absolute duty one without exceptions it applies to everyone whatever the consequences in fact Kant argued that if you told a lie which by chance led to the ax man finding your friend that would be on your conscience so if you tell the axe man that your friend is not in the house when he is and your friend then sneaks out the back door and bumps in the ax man anything that then happens is to some extent your responsibility but if you told the truth then the consequences for your friend no matter how grisly should not be on your conscience this brings out how different his moral stance was from utilitarianism the philosophy that you should do whatever brings about the greatest happiness a utilitarian would think about the consequences of telling the truth or of lying in contrast for Kant some actions were just wrong even if good consequences might flow from them this is known as a deontological approach to ethics you

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Immanuel Kant believed it would be acceptable to lie if an axe-carrying murderer was at your door.
Options: A. True, B. False
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQ**:
Question: Which philosopher argued that telling a lie to a would-be murderer is not morally acceptable, even if it could save a life?
Options: A. Immanuel Kant, B. John Stuart Mill, C. Aristotle, D. Jean-Paul Sartre
Correct Option: A

2. Evaluate each matched MCQ pair based on the following criteria:
   - **Relevance (0.0000 - 1.0000)**: Assess how closely the generated question aligns with the content and intent of the ground truth question.
   - **Correct Answer Matching (0.0000 - 1.0000)**: Check if the correct answer option in the generated question matches the ground truth answer.
   - **Distractor Plausibility (0.0000-1.0000)**: Evaluate the quality of the distractors (incorrect options) in the generated question.
   - **Clarity and Readability (0.0000-1.0000)**: Rate how clear and understandable the question and options are.

**Response Format**:
1. **MCQ Pair**: Display both the Ground Truth and Generated MCQ.
2. **Scores**:
   - Relevance Score: X.XXXX
   - Correct Answer Matching Score: X.XXXX
   - Distractor Plausibility Score: X.XXXX
   - Clarity and Readability Score: X.XXXX
   - Total Score: X.XXXX

Evaluation Response:
**MCQ Pair**

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Immanuel Kant believed it would be acceptable to lie if an axe-carrying murderer was at your door.
Options: A. True, B. False
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQ**:
Question: Which philosopher argued that telling a lie to a would-be murderer is not morally acceptable, even if it could save a life?
Options: A. Immanuel Kant, B. John Stuart Mill, C. Aristotle, D. Jean-Paul Sartre
Correct Option: A

**Scores**

- Relevance Score: 0.9000 (The generated question closely aligns with the content and intent of the ground truth question, but it is phrased differently and requires identification of the philosopher instead of a true/false response.)
- Correct Answer Matching Score: 1.0000 (The correct answer option in the generated question matches the ground truth answer, as both indicate Immanuel Kant's stance against lying.)
- Distractor Plausibility Score: 0.8000 (The distractors in the generated question are plausible, but they could be improved by including philosophers with similar views or those known for their moral and ethical theories.)
- Clarity and Readability Score: 0.9000 (The question and options are clear and understandable, but the generated question is slightly more complex due to the additional context and the need to identify the philosopher.)

**Transcript**:

Scoring Phase - Ground Truth Set 23, Ground Truth Question 1, Matched Generated Question 6
Evaluation Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript, a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), and a set of generated MCQs, your task is to:

1. Match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent of the MCQ.

**Transcript**:
The earliest known pregnancy test
dates back to 1350 BC in Ancient Egypt. According to the Egyptians, all you have to do is urinate on wheat 
and barley seeds, and wait. If either sprouts, 
congratulations, you're pregnant! And if wheat sprouts faster, it's a girl,
but if barley, it's a boy. In 1963, a small study 
reproduced this test and found that it predicted pregnancy
with a respectable 70% accuracy, though it couldn't reliably 
tell the sex of the baby. Scientists hypothesized 
that the test worked because pregnant women's urine
contains more estrogen, which can promote seed growth. Now it's easy to take 
this ancient method for granted because modern pregnancy tests give
highly accurate results within minutes. So how do they work? Over-the-counter pregnancy tests
are all designed to detect one thing: a hormone called HCG. HCG is produced in 
the earliest stages of pregnancy and starts a game of telephone that tells the body not to shed 
the inner lining of the uterus that month. As the pregnancy progresses, HCG supports the formation
of the placenta, which transfers nutrients 
from mother to fetus. The test starts when urine is applied
to the exposed end of the strip. As the fluid travels up 
the absorbent fibers, it will cross three separate zones,
each with an important task. When the wave hits the first zone,
the reaction zone, Y-shaped proteins called antibodies
will grab onto any HCG. Attached to these antibodies
is a handy enzyme with the ability to turn on dye molecules,
which will be crucial later down the road. Then the urine picks up 
all the AB1 enzymes and carries them to the test zone,
which is where the results show up. Secured to this zone are more
Y-shaped antibodies that will also stick to HCG
on one of its five binding sites. Scientists call this type of test
a sandwich assay. If HCG is present, it gets sandwiched
between the AB1 enzyme and AB2, and sticks to the test zone, allowing the attached dye-activating
enzyme to do its job and create a visible pattern. If there's no HCG, the wave of urine
and enzymes just passes on by. Finally, there's one last stop to make,
the control zone. As in any good experiment, this step confirms that 
the test is working properly. Whether the AB1 enzymes never saw HCG, or they're extras because Zone 1
is overstocked with them, all the unbound AB1 enzymes picked up
in Zone 1 should end up here and activate more dye. So if no pattern appears,
that indicates that the test was faulty. These tests are pretty reliable,
but they're not failproof. For instance, false negatives can occur if concentrations of HCG 
aren't high enough for detection. After implantation, HCG levels double
every two to three days, so it may just be too early to tell. And beverages can dilute the urine sample, which is why doctors recommend taking
the test first thing in the morning. On the other hand, false positives
can come from other sources of HCG, like IVF injections, ectopic pregnancies, or certain cancers such as uterine cancer
or testicular cancer, making it possible for one of these tests
to tell a man he's pregnant. The best way for a woman to find out 
for sure is at the doctor's office. The doctors are also looking for HCG, but with tests that are more sensitive
and quantitative, which means they can determine
the exact level of HCG in your blood. A few minutes can feel like forever when you're waiting on the results 
of a pregnancy test. But in that brief time, you're witnessing
the power of the scientific method. That one little stick 
lets you ask a question, perform a controlled experiment, and then analyze the results
to check your original hypothesis. And the best part is you won't even
have to wait until the next harvest.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which of the following is not true about human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG)?
Options: A. It is produced in the earliest stages of pregnancy, B. Levels of hCG in the body double every 2-3 days, C. Men cannot produce the hCG hormone, D. Pregnancy tests work by detecting hCG
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQ**:
Question: A man receives a false positive result on a pregnancy test. What could be a possible reason for this?
Options: A. The test was faulty, B. The man had an ectopic pregnancy, C. The man had received IVF injections or had certain cancers, D. The man had taken a medication that interfered with the test
Correct Option: C

2. Evaluate each matched MCQ pair based on the following criteria:
   - **Relevance (0.0000 - 1.0000)**: Assess how closely the generated question aligns with the content and intent of the ground truth question.
   - **Correct Answer Matching (0.0000 - 1.0000)**: Check if the correct answer option in the generated question matches the ground truth answer.
   - **Distractor Plausibility (0.0000-1.0000)**: Evaluate the quality of the distractors (incorrect options) in the generated question.
   - **Clarity and Readability (0.0000-1.0000)**: Rate how clear and understandable the question and options are.

**Response Format**:
1. **MCQ Pair**: Display both the Ground Truth and Generated MCQ.
2. **Scores**:
   - Relevance Score: X.XXXX
   - Correct Answer Matching Score: X.XXXX
   - Distractor Plausibility Score: X.XXXX
   - Clarity and Readability Score: X.XXXX
   - Total Score: X.XXXX

Evaluation Response:
**MCQ Pair**:

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which of the following is not true about human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG)?
Options: A. It is produced in the earliest stages of pregnancy, B. Levels of hCG in the body double every 2-3 days, C. Men cannot produce the hCG hormone, D. Pregnancy tests work by detecting hCG
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQ**:
Question: A man receives a false positive result on a pregnancy test. What could be a possible reason for this?
Options: A. The test was faulty, B. The man had an ectopic pregnancy, C. The man had received IVF injections or had certain cancers, D. The man had taken a medication that interfered with the test
Correct Option: C

**Scores**:
- Relevance Score: 0.8000 (The generated question is related to the ground truth question, as both deal with hCG and its implications for pregnancy tests. However, the generated question focuses on a specific scenario, whereas the ground truth question is more general.)
- Correct Answer Matching Score: 0.8000 (The correct answer in the generated question is related to the correct answer in the ground truth question. Both involve the idea that men can produce hCG under certain circumstances, which is why the statement "Men cannot produce the hCG hormone" is false.)
- Distractor Plausibility Score: 0.6000 (The distractors in the generated question are somewhat plausible, but not all of them are equally convincing. Option A, "The test was faulty," is a common reason for false positives, but it's not directly related to the specific scenario described in the question. Option D, "The man had taken a medication that interfered with the test," is not mentioned in the transcript as a possible reason for false positives.)
- Clarity and Readability Score: 0.9000 (The generated question and options are clear and easy to understand. The language is straightforward, and the scenario is well-described.)
- Total Score: 0.7750

dates back to 1350 BC in Ancient Egypt. According to the Egyptians, all you have to do is urinate on wheat 
and barley seeds, and wait. If either sprouts,

of the placenta, which transfers nutrients 
from mother to fetus. The test starts when urine is applied

is a handy enzyme with the ability to turn on dye molecules,

between the AB1 enzyme and AB2, and sticks to the test zone, allowing the attached dye-activating
enzyme to do its job and create a visible pattern. If there's no HCG, the wave of urine
and enzymes just passes on by. Finally, there's one last stop to make,
the control zone. As in any good experiment, this step confirms that 
the test is working properly. Whether the AB1 enzymes never saw HCG, or they're extras because Zone 1
is overstocked with them, all the unbound AB1 enzymes picked up
in Zone 1 should end up here and activate more dye. So if no pattern appears,
that indicates that the test was faulty. These tests are pretty reliable,
but they're not failproof. For instance, false negatives can occur if concentrations of HCG 
aren't high enough for detection. After implantation, HCG levels double
every two to three days, so it may just be too early to tell. And beverages can dilute the urine sample, which is why doctors recommend taking
the test first thing in the morning. On the other hand, false positives
can come from other sources of HCG, like IVF injections, ectopic pregnancies, or certain cancers such as uterine cancer
or testicular cancer, making it possible for one of these tests

the power of the scientific method. That one little stick 
lets you ask a question, perform a controlled experiment, and then analyze the results
to check your original hypothesis. And the best part is you won't even
have to wait until the next harvest.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which zone contains antibodies that can become dissolved in urine and pushed along the strip?
Options: A. The reaction zone, B. The test zone, C. The control zone, D. None of the above
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQ**:

Options: A. To detect the presence of HCG, B. To confirm the test is working properly, C. To attach antibodies to HCG and activate dye molecules, D. To separate HCG from other hormones
Correct Option: C

   - **Relevance (0.0000 - 1.0000)**: Assess how closely the generated question aligns with the content and intent of the ground truth question.

The earliest known pregnancy test
dates back to 1350 BC in Ancient Egypt. According to the Egyptians, all you have to do is urinate on wheat 
and barley seeds, and wait. If either sprouts,

with a respectable 70% accuracy, though it couldn't reliably

that the test worked because pregnant women's urine
contains more estrogen, which can promote seed growth. Now it's easy to take

are all designed to detect one thing: a hormone called HCG. HCG is produced in 
the earliest stages of pregnancy and starts a game of telephone that tells the body not to shed 
the inner lining of the uterus that month. As the pregnancy progresses, HCG supports the formation
of the placenta, which transfers nutrients 
from mother to fetus. The test starts when urine is applied
to the exposed end of the strip. As the fluid travels up 
the absorbent fibers, it will cross three separate zones,
each with an important task. When the wave hits the first zone,

will grab onto any HCG. Attached to these antibodies

and enzymes just passes on by. Finally, there's one last stop to make,

the test is working properly. Whether the AB1 enzymes never saw HCG, or they're extras because Zone 1
is overstocked with them, all the unbound AB1 enzymes picked up

and quantitative, which means they can determine
the exact level of HCG in your blood. A few minutes can feel like forever when you're waiting on the results 
of a pregnancy test. But in that brief time, you're witnessing
the power of the scientific method. That one little stick 
lets you ask a question, perform a controlled experiment, and then analyze the results
to check your original hypothesis. And the best part is you won't even
have to wait until the next harvest.

Scoring Phase - Ground Truth Set 23, Ground Truth Question 4, Matched Generated Question 4

**Transcript**:
The earliest known pregnancy test
dates back to 1350 BC in Ancient Egypt. According to the Egyptians, all you have to do is urinate on wheat 
and barley seeds, and wait. If either sprouts, 
congratulations, you're pregnant! And if wheat sprouts faster, it's a girl,
but if barley, it's a boy. In 1963, a small study

lets you ask a question, perform a controlled experiment, and then analyze the results
to check your original hypothesis. And the best part is you won't even
have to wait until the next harvest.

Options: A. Reaction zone antibodies bind to hCG, B. Reaction zone antibodies get stuck here and activate dye molecules, C. Reaction zone antibodies, hCG and test zone antibodies bind to make a "sandwich", D. Reaction zone antibodies get picked up and pushed along the stick by the urine
Correct Option: B

Scoring Phase - Ground Truth Set 23, Ground Truth Question 5, Matched Generated Question 9
Evaluation Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript, a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), and a set of generated MCQs, your task is to:

1. Match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent of the MCQ.

**Transcript**:
The earliest known pregnancy test
dates back to 1350 BC in Ancient Egypt. According to the Egyptians, all you have to do is urinate on wheat 
and barley seeds, and wait. If either sprouts, 
congratulations, you're pregnant! And if wheat sprouts faster, it's a girl,
but if barley, it's a boy. In 1963, a small study 
reproduced this test and found that it predicted pregnancy
with a respectable 70% accuracy, though it couldn't reliably 
tell the sex of the baby. Scientists hypothesized 
that the test worked because pregnant women's urine
contains more estrogen, which can promote seed growth. Now it's easy to take 
this ancient method for granted because modern pregnancy tests give
highly accurate results within minutes. So how do they work? Over-the-counter pregnancy tests
are all designed to detect one thing: a hormone called HCG. HCG is produced in 
the earliest stages of pregnancy and starts a game of telephone that tells the body not to shed 
the inner lining of the uterus that month. As the pregnancy progresses, HCG supports the formation
of the placenta, which transfers nutrients 
from mother to fetus. The test starts when urine is applied
to the exposed end of the strip. As the fluid travels up 
the absorbent fibers, it will cross three separate zones,
each with an important task. When the wave hits the first zone,
the reaction zone, Y-shaped proteins called antibodies
will grab onto any HCG. Attached to these antibodies
is a handy enzyme with the ability to turn on dye molecules,
which will be crucial later down the road. Then the urine picks up 
all the AB1 enzymes and carries them to the test zone,
which is where the results show up. Secured to this zone are more
Y-shaped antibodies that will also stick to HCG
on one of its five binding sites. Scientists call this type of test
a sandwich assay. If HCG is present, it gets sandwiched
between the AB1 enzyme and AB2, and sticks to the test zone, allowing the attached dye-activating
enzyme to do its job and create a visible pattern. If there's no HCG, the wave of urine
and enzymes just passes on by. Finally, there's one last stop to make,
the control zone. As in any good experiment, this step confirms that 
the test is working properly. Whether the AB1 enzymes never saw HCG, or they're extras because Zone 1
is overstocked with them, all the unbound AB1 enzymes picked up
in Zone 1 should end up here and activate more dye. So if no pattern appears,
that indicates that the test was faulty. These tests are pretty reliable,
but they're not failproof. For instance, false negatives can occur if concentrations of HCG 
aren't high enough for detection. After implantation, HCG levels double
every two to three days, so it may just be too early to tell. And beverages can dilute the urine sample, which is why doctors recommend taking
the test first thing in the morning. On the other hand, false positives
can come from other sources of HCG, like IVF injections, ectopic pregnancies, or certain cancers such as uterine cancer
or testicular cancer, making it possible for one of these tests
to tell a man he's pregnant. The best way for a woman to find out 
for sure is at the doctor's office. The doctors are also looking for HCG, but with tests that are more sensitive
and quantitative, which means they can determine
the exact level of HCG in your blood. A few minutes can feel like forever when you're waiting on the results 
of a pregnancy test. But in that brief time, you're witnessing
the power of the scientific method. That one little stick 
lets you ask a question, perform a controlled experiment, and then analyze the results
to check your original hypothesis. And the best part is you won't even
have to wait until the next harvest.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which zone does not contain any dye molecules waiting to be activated?
Options: A. The reaction zone, B. The test zone, C. The control zone, D. None of the above
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQ**:
Question: What is the purpose of the reaction zone in a pregnancy test?
Options: A. To detect the presence of HCG, B. To confirm the test is working properly, C. To attach antibodies to HCG and activate dye molecules, D. To separate HCG from other hormones
Correct Option: C

2. Evaluate each matched MCQ pair based on the following criteria:
   - **Relevance (0.0000 - 1.0000)**: Assess how closely the generated question aligns with the content and intent of the ground truth question.
   - **Correct Answer Matching (0.0000 - 1.0000)**: Check if the correct answer option in the generated question matches the ground truth answer.
   - **Distractor Plausibility (0.0000-1.0000)**: Evaluate the quality of the distractors (incorrect options) in the generated question.
   - **Clarity and Readability (0.0000-1.0000)**: Rate how clear and understandable the question and options are.

**Response Format**:

   - Relevance Score: X.XXXX
   - Correct Answer Matching Score: X.XXXX
   - Distractor Plausibility Score: X.XXXX
   - Clarity and Readability Score: X.XXXX
   - Total Score: X.XXXX

Question: Which zone does not contain any dye molecules waiting to be activated?
Options: A. The reaction zone, B. The test zone, C. The control zone, D. None of the above
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQ**:

Options: A. To detect the presence of HCG, B. To confirm the test is working properly, C. To attach antibodies to HCG and activate dye molecules, D. To separate HCG from other hormones

**Transcript**:
[Music] this is the story of how cholera changed my village tiny germs of cholera too small to see spread through the river so small yet so dangerous without realizing women carried cholera home in the water flies carried cholera on their feet unwashed hands spread it too we swallowed cholera germs in our water on our food and on our fingers [Music] it happened so fast by morning my father was very sick he had diarrhea that looked like rainwater and poured out of him I was so scared I went for help I [Music] never rode so fast one look at my father and the nurse knew it was cholera we had to work fast to save him we made a special drink to help him first we made the water safe we filtered it through cloth and boiled it for one minute then we mixed half a teaspoon of salt and six teaspoons of sugar in one liter of this safe water he tasted like tears not too salty I worried my father would die before my eyes but he soon felt a little stronger the nurse explained to me that not everyone who swallows cholera germs get sick like my father but they can still spread the disease now I needed to takes a father to my village and teach them how to protect themselves from cholera I saw a girl carrying water I told her she could make the water safe by adding chlorine drops and waiting half an hour [Music] there was a man about to eat with unclean hands I told him to always wash his hands with soap and safe water after going to the toilet only with clean hands could heat safely I saw villagers spreading cholera into a river I told them we needed to dig latrines far from the river at least 30 meters away this was important to keep our village clean I found the mother preparing unsafe food I told her first we must wash our hands with safe water then we had to wash and peel the food cook it and always eat it hot and protected from flies I spread the word throughout my village and ran to find my father I was so happy to see he was better our village became healthy now a filter and oil our water to make sure it is safe we always use that Trine's and always wash our hands after food is safe from flies washed and peeled and cooked and we always wash our hands before cooking and eating [Applause] we made our village safe from cholera spread the word your village can be safe [Music]
